Welcome to Phaseflow’s documentation!¶

benchmarks.py applies Phaseflow to a variety of benchmark problems.

class phaseflow.benchmarks.AdaptiveLidDrivenCavityWithSolidSubdomain(automatic_jacobian=False)[source]¶

Bases: phaseflow.benchmarks.LidDrivenCavityWithSolidSubdomain

Adaptively solve the lid-driven cavity with solid subdomain example.

Ideally we should be able to use AMR instead of manually refining the prescribed PCI. Unfortunately, the adaptive solver computes an error estimate of exactly 0, which seems to be a bug in FEniCS. We’ll want to make a MWE and investigate. For now let’s leave this failing benchmark here.

Methods

refine_near_y_pci([pci_refinement_cycles])
run()
setup_model([timestep_size, automatic_jacobian])
verify() Verify against cite{ghia1982}.
verify_scalar_solution_component(component, …)
class phaseflow.benchmarks.LidDrivenCavityWithSolidSubdomain(mesh_size=[20, 25], pci_refinement_cycles=4, timestep_size=20.0, automatic_jacobian=False)[source]¶

Bases: phaseflow.benchmarks.LidDrivenCavity

Similar to the lid-driven cavity, but extended with a solid subdomain to test variable viscosity.

The unit square from the original benchmark is prescribed a temperature which makes it fluid, while below the original bottom wall, a cold temperature is prescribed, making it solid.

Methods

core.py contains the core functionality.

Bases: phaseflow.core.BoundedValue

This class implements a bounded adaptive time step size.

set(value)

helpers.py contains a variety of generally useful code.

Containing this code here cleans up the other modules which are more specific to our problem of interest.

phaseflow.helpers.arguments()[source]¶

Returns tuple containing dictionary of calling function’s named arguments and a list of calling function’s unnamed positional arguments.

phaseflow.helpers.mkdir_p(path)[source]¶

Make a directory if it doesn’t exist. Code from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/600268/mkdir-p-functionality-in-python

pure.py contains code specific to pure materials.

For example, this is useful for pure water, but not for salt water.

class phaseflow.pure.GebhartWaterBuoyancy(hot_temperature, cold_temperature, rayleigh_numer, prandtl_number, gravity=[0.0, -1.0])[source]¶

Bases: phaseflow.core.ContinuousFunction

Water buoyancy model centered around the density anomaly, published in cite{gebhart1977}.

Methods

__call__(arg) Call self as a function.
phaseflow.pure.make_mixed_element(mesh_ufl_cell, pressure_degree=1, temperature_degree=1)[source]¶

An attempt was made to define this as a sub-class of fenics.MixedElement, instead of as a function; but DOLFIN’s JIT compiler was throwing an error related to its __repr attribute.

pure_with_constant_properties.py contains code specific to pure materials with constant properties.

For example, this is useful for an octadecane phase-change material.
